text: in the past decade that there's been a
boom in the production of natural gas in
the United States aided by a technique
called hydraulic fracturing or fracking
at the same time Oklahoma and other
states were fracking is widespread have
experienced rising numbers of small
earthquakes our quakes and fracking
related scientists say the link is
mostly indirect they say disposal wells
where wastewater is injected deep
underground are of greater concern in
fracking water and chemicals are
injected at very high pressure into
wells to break up rock formations and
release gas trapped within them when the
rocks break they create what scientists
call micro seismic events very small
tremors that are barely detectable and
caused no damage to structures above
ground
occasionally fracking may cause a larger
quick one that could result in minor
damage that's because it's the fracking
liquid travels into the rock formation
it alters pressures underground if there
are old earthquake faults there the
pressure changes may be enough to allow
the rocks to slip but fracking uses
relatively small amounts of liquid and
so far has only been linked to a few
larger quakes
scientists say that disposal wells are
potentially a bigger problem and have
already been linked to more at a time
stronger earthquakes in these wells an
enormous amount of wastewater from
fracking and other oil and gas
production methods is pumped into rock
formations that can change pressures
over a wider area increasing the risk
for a number of quakes
